keyTakeAways: Oklahoma’s new Superintendent, Lindel Fields, has rescinded a mandate from his predecessor, Ryan Walters, requiring Bibles to be placed in classrooms and included in lesson plans for grades 5–12.

The Bible mandate, introduced by former Superintendent Ryan Walters, drew strong condemnation from civil rights groups and triggered a pending lawsuit from parents, teachers, and religious leaders before the Oklahoma Supreme Court.

Superintendent Fields stated that there are no plans to distribute Bibles or implement a Biblical character education curriculum in schools, emphasizing district autonomy and taxpayer resource allocation.

The state education department plans to review all directives from former Superintendent Walters, including a controversial ideology exam for teachers from California and New York, to assess their continued validity.
Oklahoma Gov. Kevin Stitt appointed Fields to the superintendent role after Walters resigned to take a position in the private sector.
Attorneys for the plaintiffs in the lawsuit welcomed the rescission and intend to discuss next steps with their clients.
Many school districts across Oklahoma had previously chosen not to comply with the Bible mandate, indicating widespread resistance to religious instruction in public schools.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Oklahoma’s new school superintendent, Lindel Fields, has rescinded a mandate introduced by his predecessor, Ryan Walters, which required Bibles to be placed in classrooms and integrated into student lesson plans for grades 5–12. The directive, which drew widespread criticism from civil rights groups and sparked a pending lawsuit before the Oklahoma Supreme Court, was seen as an effort to promote religion in public education. Fields emphasized that the decision on religious instruction should remain with individual school districts and rejected spending taxpayer funds on Bibles. He also announced a broader review of all mandates from Walters’ administration, including controversial teacher ideology exams for applicants from California and New York. This move reflects a shift toward educational neutrality and accountability, with legal and public support for ending religiously driven classroom policies.
title: New Oklahoma Schools Superintendent Rescinds Mandate for Bible Instruction in Schools
